At the meeting of the Johns HopInterfraternity

Board next Thursday the acceptance
of a new constitution for that body
is to be voted upon. The new constitution has been drawn up and is
now ready to be submitted for approval.
Six Articles in Constitution

There has been some amount of
discontent in regard to the Interfraternity Board's constitution and
at times a difference of opinion
among the members of the Board
themselves. It is hoped that by the
adoption of the new constitution a
great amount of this will be brought
to an end. The constitution as it
is to be submitted consists of a
Preamble and six Articles. The
Preamble reads as follows:
"We, the undersigned fraternities
at the Johns Hopkins University,
believing that, for the promotion of
friendly relations 'between the various chapters, and for the betterment of the conditions of fraternity
life and fraternity membership at
the Johns Hopkins University, some
form of interfraternity agreement
is desirable, do hereby adopt and
agree to be governed by the following articles, pledging ourselves to
obey their spirit as well as their
letter."
The first article is composed of
three sections concerning first the
name of the Board and the duty of
the Board. The section concerning
the duty of the Board is as follows:
"Section 2: It shall be the special
duty of the Board to regulate the
rushing, bidding, and pledging by
the signatory fraternities of men in
their first year of residence at the
University."

.Some day perhaps, the NEWSLETTER will incorporate within its
columns a "believe-it-or-not" section. Until that distant date such
matters must be given attention in
this column.
A week or so ago we told how,
in filling out a civil service application the query "Do you drink? If
so, how much?" must be answered.
At that time it seemed impossible to
think of a more illogical•question to
ask a poor college senior applying
for a job. But, believe it or not, the
application blank of the Bethlehem
Steel Co., in addition to inquiring
of the applicants interest in literature also wants to know just how
much he likes music.
That the Honor System is still
in full force at Hopkins is exemplified by the following: It seems. that
a certain instructor wanted to take
a day off. So he made out a quiz
and gave it to one of the other instructors to give to the "boys." This
second instructor later decided to
take the day off also. He took the
quiz, sealed it in an envelope, and
gave it to one of the men to open at
the beginning of the qquiz period.
A few days ago a unusually
down trodden "down-and-out" specimen of the Pratt street panhandler
wandered into the M. E. senior

room begging for carfare to go out
and see a friend. After telling of
his engineering experience to all
those who would listen he again
asked for the two nickels.
At first it appeared he was up
against it, since he was unable to
change the dollar bill offered him
by a prominent lacrosse goal-keeper,
Karl W. Flocks, under promise to
mention his name in this article dug
down in his jeans and produced
eight cents which he presented to
the man. The panhandler was then
sent to visit various instructors.
The first instructor, feeling sorry
for the man; and like most instructors being relatively poor borrowed
ten cents from a Senior and gave it
to the alleged bum.
After trying the doors of several
other professors' offices and finding
them not at home the man in question wandered further into other
portions of the building where he
is reported to have accumulated the
additional sum of.40 cents.
The "Junior M. E.'s in the spirit
of pure fun opened up a window in
the Senior room and threw a bucket
full of roof on the desks through
it. The gravel rather smeared things
up, but so far nothing has happened to the Junior room.
H. F. M., Jr.

NINE GAMES LISTED
All Positions on Team are Still
Open
The Johns Hopkins Lacrosse team
is now practicing for another national championship. Last year was
the first time in many years past
that Hopkins was not the national
champion, and it looks as if. this
year the Jays will return to their
old status.
Practice is being held every afternoon at the Homewood field and
already promising material is beginning to shine forth, and the veterans are beginning to hit their old
stride. There are several Freshman, former prep-school stars, who
look as if they might give the veterans a job to get their old places
back. Last year one of the main reasons for the comparatively weak
team was the fact that it was made
up almost entirely of inexperienced
men. However, as only four men,
on the team last year, were Seniors,
there is almost the entire team back
again this year.
Men Who Graduated

The men who graduated were
Herpsberger, Kegan, Caplan, and
Eagan. These men were all very valuable to the team but there should
be no trouble in filling their positions. There are at least five men in
the Freshman Class who starred in
prep-school and who will have a
chance of making the team in their
first year. George Packard, from
Marston, was considered one of the
best centers playing on any prepschool team in the State. Jack Turnbull was one of the best lacrosse
players in the country last year.
Turnbull can play any position on
the team but excells on the attack
or at center position. Jimmie McCabe, also of Marston, plays on the
defense and has a good chance of
filling one of the open positions.
McDorman, of Poly, and Triplett,
of City, are also good material.

EDITORIALS

"On the Route of the Charles Street Bus"

HOT TIMES AT HARVARD
E Harvard Crimson, in conjunction with the college debating society, has recently entered into a campaign to modify the Eighteenth Amendment. They have solicited the support of college newspapers throughout the country and some interest has been aroused
concerning the attitude which the NEWS-Letter intends to take on
the matter.
We will not join with the Crimson in its anti-Volstead crusade.
The reason for not taking part in the movement is not that we disapprove of the object which the Crimson desires to attain. We believe,
however, that a college newspaper exists for.two purposes: to bring
news items of general college interest to the students and to influence
campus opinion as much as may be possible on topics pertaining to
college. The discussion of national problems can find no legitimate
place in the columns of the NEWS-LETTER or in any other college sheet
except those published by certain mid-western institutions which serve
as town papers. College papers should discuss college questions; papers
which serve both colleges and towns should carry items of interest to
both, but neither the NEWS-LETTER or the Crimson are members of
the latter class.
Furthermore, the editors of college papers should not express their
views on national questions for purely ethical reasons. The college
editor is chosen for his familiarity with regards to college matters. His
opinions on the World Court, on the selection of Mr. Hughes as Chief
Justice, the outcome of Mussolini's dictatorship and like matters are
not considered in his choice. Therefore, if he utilizes the privilege
given him of commenting on student affairs to divulge his own opinions
on totally irrelevant topics, he breaks faith with his electors.
The Crimson should not be unqualifiedly reproached for its campaign, because it is only spreading the views of another campus activity, namely, the debating society. It is the duty of the editor to
report to the students all projects undertaken by the undergraduates.
Furthermore he should comment editorially upon matters of real
importance. But to crusade against conditions which are not within
his field, however evil he may think them to be, is to overstep the
bounds of both modesty and common sense.

DEBATING AT HOPKINS
HE furor caused by the Harvard Debating Society leads us to consider the growing lack of interest in debating at Hopkins. Some
time back, debating was the foremost among college activities but at
Hopkins today it holds an appeal for such a small number of students
that its very existence is hanging in the balance.
Various reasons have been assigned for this decline in interest, chief
• among them being that the youth of today does not desire to go in for
anything which faintly smacks of the intellectual. It is charged that
the tempo of college life has been speeded up so greatly that the
leisure necessary for both the preparation and attendance at debates
is lacking.
We believe that the real reason for the conditions existing at Hopkins is to be found in the fact that other activities have become increasingly more pleasant, not that debating has grown less so. A
decade or two ago, debating was almost the only extra-curricular activity, but with the growth of publications, athletics, and dramatic
clubs many adherents of oratory have necessarily found their way into
other fields.
• We predict that the Debating Council has not yet reached its nadir
and that the passing of the council from the ranks of activities is only
a matter of time.

1929-30 REGISTER
The University Register for
1929-1930, has just been issued and may be obtained
upon application at the registrar's office.
The register contains a
short historical statement, an
account of the organization
of the University, lists of the
faculty, fellows and students,
and maps of the Homewood
campus and the medical school.
The faculty list gives the
names of the faculty members,
their positions, degrees, and
their address. That of the fellows gives their degrees, address and the fellowship they
hold. The student list contains
the names of the students, together with their degrees, if
any, the courses they are pursuing, and their home and
present addresses.

At the meeting of the Johns HopInterfraternity
University
kins
Board next Thursday the acceptance
of a new constitution for that body
is to be voted upon. The new constitution has been drawn up and is
now ready to be submitted for approval.
Six Articles in Constitution

There has been some amount of
discontent in regard to the Interfraternity Board's constitution and
at times a difference of opinion
among the members of the Board
themselves. It is hoped that by the
adoption of the new constitution a
great amount of this will be brought
to an end. The constitution as it
is to be submitted consists of a
Preamble and six Articles. The
Preamble reads as follows:
"We, the undersigned fraternities
at the Johns Hopkins University,
believing that, for the promotion of
friendly relations 'between the various chapters, and for the betterment of the conditions of fraternity
life and fraternity membership at
the Johns Hopkins University, some
form of interfraternity agreement
is desirable, do hereby adopt and
agree to be governed by the following articles, pledging ourselves to
obey their spirit as well as their
letter."
The first article is composed of
three sections concerning first the
name of the Board and the duty of
the Board. The section concerning
the duty of the Board is as follows:
"Section 2: It shall be the special
duty of the Board to regulate the
rushing, bidding, and pledging by
the signatory fraternities of men in
their first year of residence at the
University."

.Some day perhaps, the NEWSLETTER will incorporate within its
columns a "believe-it-or-not" section. Until that distant date such
matters must be given attention in
this column.
A week or so ago we told how,
in filling out a civil service application the query "Do you drink? If
so, how much?" must be answered.
At that time it seemed impossible to
think of a more illogical•question to
ask a poor college senior applying
for a job. But, believe it or not, the
application blank of the Bethlehem
Steel Co., in addition to inquiring
of the applicants interest in literature also wants to know just how
much he likes music.
That the Honor System is still
in full force at Hopkins is exemplified by the following: It seems. that
a certain instructor wanted to take
a day off. So he made out a quiz
and gave it to one of the other instructors to give to the "boys." This
second instructor later decided to
take the day off also. He took the
quiz, sealed it in an envelope, and
gave it to one of the men to open at
the beginning of the qquiz period.
A few days ago a unusually
down trodden "down-and-out" specimen of the Pratt street panhandler
wandered into the M. E. senior

room begging for carfare to go out
and see a friend. After telling of
his engineering experience to all
those who would listen he again
asked for the two nickels.
At first it appeared he was up
against it, since he was unable to
change the dollar bill offered him
by a prominent lacrosse goal-keeper,
Karl W. Flocks, under promise to
mention his name in this article dug
down in his jeans and produced
eight cents which he presented to
the man. The panhandler was then
sent to visit various instructors.
The first instructor, feeling sorry
for the man; and like most instructors being relatively poor borrowed
ten cents from a Senior and gave it
to the alleged bum.
After trying the doors of several
other professors' offices and finding
them not at home the man in question wandered further into other
portions of the building where he
is reported to have accumulated the
additional sum of.40 cents.
The "Junior M. E.'s in the spirit
of pure fun opened up a window in
the Senior room and threw a bucket
full of roof on the desks through
it. The gravel rather smeared things
up, but so far nothing has happened to the Junior room.
H. F. M., Jr.

All Positions on Team are Still

The Johns Hopkins Lacrosse team
is now practicing for another national championship. Last year was
the first time in many years past
that Hopkins was not the national
champion, and it looks as if. this
year the Jays will return to their
old status.
Practice is being held every afternoon at the Homewood field and
already promising material is beginning to shine forth, and the veterans are beginning to hit their old
stride. There are several Freshman, former prep-school stars, who
look as if they might give the veterans a job to get their old places
back. Last year one of the main reasons for the comparatively weak
team was the fact that it was made
up almost entirely of inexperienced
men. However, as only four men,
on the team last year, were Seniors,
there is almost the entire team back
again this year.
Men Who Graduated

The men who graduated were
Herpsberger, Kegan, Caplan, and
Eagan. These men were all very valuable to the team but there should
be no trouble in filling their positions. There are at least five men in
the Freshman Class who starred in
prep-school and who will have a
chance of making the team in their
first year. George Packard, from
Marston, was considered one of the
best centers playing on any prepschool team in the State. Jack Turnbull was one of the best lacrosse
players in the country last year.
Turnbull can play any position on
the team but excells on the attack
or at center position. Jimmie McCabe, also of Marston, plays on the
defense and has a good chance of
filling one of the open positions.
McDorman, of Poly, and Triplett,
of City, are also good material.

HOT TIMES AT HARVARD
E Harvard Crimson, in conjunction with the college debating society, has recently entered into a campaign to modify the Eighteenth Amendment. They have solicited the support of college newspapers throughout the country and some interest has been aroused
concerning the attitude which the NEWS-Letter intends to take on
the matter.
We will not join with the Crimson in its anti-Volstead crusade.
The reason for not taking part in the movement is not that we disapprove of the object which the Crimson desires to attain. We believe,
however, that a college newspaper exists for.two purposes: to bring
news items of general college interest to the students and to influence
campus opinion as much as may be possible on topics pertaining to
college. The discussion of national problems can find no legitimate
place in the columns of the NEWS-LETTER or in any other college sheet
except those published by certain mid-western institutions which serve
as town papers. College papers should discuss college questions; papers
which serve both colleges and towns should carry items of interest to
both, but neither the NEWS-LETTER or the Crimson are members of
the latter class.
Furthermore, the editors of college papers should not express their
views on national questions for purely ethical reasons. The college
editor is chosen for his familiarity with regards to college matters. His
opinions on the World Court, on the selection of Mr. Hughes as Chief
Justice, the outcome of Mussolini's dictatorship and like matters are
not considered in his choice. Therefore, if he utilizes the privilege
given him of commenting on student affairs to divulge his own opinions
on totally irrelevant topics, he breaks faith with his electors.
The Crimson should not be unqualifiedly reproached for its campaign, because it is only spreading the views of another campus activity, namely, the debating society. It is the duty of the editor to
report to the students all projects undertaken by the undergraduates.
Furthermore he should comment editorially upon matters of real
importance. But to crusade against conditions which are not within
his field, however evil he may think them to be, is to overstep the
bounds of both modesty and common sense.

DEBATING AT HOPKINS
HE furor caused by the Harvard Debating Society leads us to consider the growing lack of interest in debating at Hopkins. Some
time back, debating was the foremost among college activities but at
Hopkins today it holds an appeal for such a small number of students
that its very existence is hanging in the balance.
Various reasons have been assigned for this decline in interest, chief
• among them being that the youth of today does not desire to go in for
anything which faintly smacks of the intellectual. It is charged that
the tempo of college life has been speeded up so greatly that the
leisure necessary for both the preparation and attendance at debates
is lacking.
We believe that the real reason for the conditions existing at Hopkins is to be found in the fact that other activities have become increasingly more pleasant, not that debating has grown less so. A
decade or two ago, debating was almost the only extra-curricular activity, but with the growth of publications, athletics, and dramatic
clubs many adherents of oratory have necessarily found their way into
other fields.
• We predict that the Debating Council has not yet reached its nadir
and that the passing of the council from the ranks of activities is only
a matter of time.

UNIVERSITY ISSUES
1929-30 REGISTER
The University Register for
1929-1930, has just been issued and may be obtained
upon application at the registrar's office.
The register contains a
short historical statement, an
account of the organization
of the University, lists of the
faculty, fellows and students,
and maps of the Homewood
campus and the medical school.
The faculty list gives the
names of the faculty members,
their positions, degrees, and
their address. That of the fellows gives their degrees, address and the fellowship they
hold. The student list contains
the names of the students, together with their degrees, if
any, the courses they are pursuing, and their home and
present addresses.
